<summary>
• Our understanding of H. pylori-induced inflammation leading to cancer is built on the work of three pioneering pathologists: Rudolf Virchow, Pelayo Correa, and Robin Warren. Virchow proposed that cancer arose from normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation.

• Pelayo Correa developed a model for gastric cancer development, hypothesizing a stepwise process from chronic atrophic gastritis to cancer over decades. He initially thought environmental factors were responsible but later focused on H. pylori's role.

• Robin Warren and Barry Marshall discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, earning them the Nobel Prize in 2005. Their work laid the foundation for understanding H. pylori's link to gastric cancer.

• Initial studies in the 1980s and 1990s provided weak evidence for a link between H. pylori and gastric cancer. More convincing evidence came from large cohort studies showing a significant association between prior H. pylori infection and subsequent gastric cancer development.

• The World Health Organization classified H. pylori as a definite carcinogen in 1994. Subsequent research confirmed H. pylori's role in both intestinal and diffuse types of gastric cancer.

• H. pylori eradication has been shown to reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer. Recent meta-analyses indicate a 40% risk reduction in asymptomatic individuals and a 54% reduction in preventing second gastric malignancies.

• Population-based H. pylori eradication efforts have shown promising results in high-risk areas like Taiwan and China. However, there is hesitation in the developed world due to concerns about H. pylori's potential protective effect against esophageal adenocarcinoma.

• H. pylori's disappearance from the human microbiome has been linked to various contemporary maladies, although the evidence is questionable. The decrease in noncardia gastric cancer in North America and Western Europe coincided with decreasing H. pylori prevalence.

• Future research aims to stratify individuals with H. pylori infection into high vs. low gastric cancer risk. This could lead to personalized surveillance, chemoprevention, and dietary intervention programs for those at highest risk.
</summary>

<summary>
• Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) is a leading cause of visual loss among the elderly, and treatments like bevacizumab and ranibizumab have shown effectiveness in preventing visual acuity (VA) loss and even improving VA in some patients. 
• The study compared the functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab in Turkish patients with nAMD, using a retrospective evaluation of clinical data from 2009 to 2011. 
• Inclusion criteria included age 50 or older, newly diagnosed nAMD, and no prior treatments other than bevacizumab or ranibizumab, with a minimum follow-up period of 12 months.

• Both groups showed significant improvements in mean best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT) at all time points compared to baseline. 
• There was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in terms of changes in BCVA and CRT at any time point. 
• The mean number of injections at month 12 was similar between the bevacizumab and ranibizumab groups, with no significant difference.

• The study found that 86.1% of patients in the bevacizumab group and 86.5% in the ranibizumab group had stable or improved vision. 
• Mild complications such as punctate keratitis, subconjunctival hemorrhage, and transient mild anterior uveitis were observed, but no serious ocular or systemic complications occurred. 
• Previous studies also reported similar visual and anatomical outcomes between bevacizumab and ranibizumab.

• The CATT study, a multicenter noninferiority trial, found no significant difference in visual acuity and anatomical outcomes between the two drugs at 12 and 24 months. 
• The mean injection numbers were also similar between the two drugs in the CATT study. 
• Safety concerns remain a topic of debate, with some studies indicating a higher rate of serious adverse events in the bevacizumab group, though not statistically significant.

• The study's strengths include the fact that patients had received no other forms of treatment and had similar baseline characteristics. 
• The findings suggest that both bevacizumab and ranibizumab are effective in stabilizing or improving visual acuity in nAMD patients over an average follow-up period of 18 months. 
• The results align with previous studies, indicating that both drugs provide similar visual and anatomical benefits.
</summary>

<summary>
* Preeclampsia (PE) is a major cause of maternal and neonatal mortality and morbidity, affecting 25% of pregnancies. Traditionally, proteinuria in women with gestational hypertension is used to diagnose PE, but recent studies suggest proteinuria is not a significant predictor of adverse outcomes. The incidence of PE has increased in China with the two-child policy, but this does not indicate severe PE. Severe PE is often associated with hypoalbuminemia, which may serve as an indicator of PE severity.

* Hypoalbuminemia in PE is caused by systemic small vessel spasm, increased angiotensin secretion, and damaged vascular endothelial cells, leading to protein leakage and intravascular dehydration. This dehydration can accelerate intravascular lesions, predisposing to HELLP syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Reduced hepatic blood flow due to decreased albumin production further complicates the condition. Recent studies suggest maintaining adequate blood protein levels during early pregnancy may prevent PE.

* The study aimed to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE based on albumin levels. A retrospective cohort study included 299 women from Anhui Province, China, between January 2014 and June 2015. Ethics approval was obtained, and participants provided written informed consent. Serum albumin was measured, and PE was defined according to international guidelines.

* Exclusion criteria included kidney diseases, preexisting proteinuria, essential hypertension, other chronic conditions, and twin pregnancies. Maternal outcomes evaluated included delivery mode, eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, hypertension, liver and renal function, ascites, oligohydramnios, thrombocytopenia, and abruptio placenta. Neonatal outcomes included perinatal deaths, preterm birth, neonatal asphyxia, and fetal growth restriction. Statistical analyses were performed using t-tests, chi-square tests, and univariate logistic regression.

* The study identified 309 women with singleton pregnancies, excluding ten due to incomplete data. No significant differences in age and BMI were found between the mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) and severe hypoproteinemia (SHP) groups. Women with SHP delivered 1.5 weeks earlier than those with MHP. The SHP group had higher cesarean section rates and lower spontaneous delivery rates.

* Severe hypertension, abnormal liver or renal function, ascites, and abruptio placenta were more frequent in the SHP group. Neonatal outcomes were worse in the SHP group, with lower average birth weights and higher rates of fetal growth

<summary>
• The development of humanized monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) like Avastin and small-molecule protein tyrosine kinase (PTK) inhibitors has advanced the targeting of the VEGF-A signaling pathway in cancer treatment. However, Avastin's withdrawal for breast cancer treatment in the U.S. highlights the limitations and need for careful cost-benefit analysis of anti-angiogenic treatments.
• Resistance to Avastin and pre-existing refractoriness in some tumors suggest other growth factors like VEGF-C, VEGF-D, and fibroblast growth factor (FGF) may promote tumor angiogenesis. Mechanisms such as vascular mimicry and altered tumor metabolism also contribute to resistance.
• Placental growth factor (PlGF) and VEGF-B, ligands for VEGFR-1, have context-dependent roles in cancer, with PlGF potentially modulating VEGF-A effects and VEGF-B being more relevant to cardiovascular diseases. Overexpression of VEGF-B in a mouse model of pancreatic cancer suppressed tumor growth.
• VEGF-C and VEGF-D promote tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, with VEGF-C being a high-affinity ligand for VEGFR-2 and VEGF-D associated with poor patient outcomes in some cancers. Targeting VEGF-D signaling could inhibit both tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis.
• Agents targeting VEGF family members and their receptors are in various development stages, with mAbs being evaluated for their efficacy as anti-cancer agents. Identifying specific cancer indications and appropriate biomarkers will be crucial for their clinical success.
</summary>

<summary>
• Malaria remains a significant public health concern in Iran, especially in the southern and southeastern regions, with control measures reducing cases from 11,460 in 2008 to 3,239 in 2011. Plasmodium vivax is the predominant species, while Plasmodium falciparum accounts for 10-15% of cases. Iran has been in the malaria pre-elimination phase since 2009, focusing on prevention, active case detection, and timely treatment.

• Asymptomatic malaria infections, often undetectable by traditional methods, pose a challenge in endemic regions. Accurate detection methods are crucial for identifying all parasite carriers to achieve malaria elimination. Light microscopy remains the standard diagnostic method, but its limitations necessitate complementary techniques.

• Rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) are used in remote settings where microscopy is impractical, and molecular methods like nested-PCR offer high sensitivity for detecting sub-clinical parasitemia. This study aimed to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections using microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR in Bagh-e-Malek, Minab district, Hormozgan province. The study involved 200 healthy volunteers, with blood samples collected for analysis.

• The study area, Bagh-e-Malek, is a lowland region with a population of 1,451, experiencing two annual malaria peaks in May and October. The region reported 15 malaria cases in 2011, predominantly caused by Plasmodium vivax. Blood samples were collected from participants in July 2011, with follow-up samples taken 30 and 60 days later.

• Microscopic examination of blood smears and RDTs found no malaria parasites in any of the 200 samples. However, nested-PCR detected Plasmodium vivax in 3 samples (1.5%), which were missed by microscopy and RDTs. These cases were asymptomatic and remained symptomless during follow-up evaluations.

• The study highlights the importance of using molecular methods like nested-PCR for detecting asymptomatic malaria carriers, especially in the elimination phase. Microscopy and RDTs, while useful, have limitations in detecting low parasite densities and asymptomatic infections. Combining these methods with molecular techniques can improve sensitivity, specificity, and reliability in malaria surveillance.

• The findings emphasize the need for a multi-faceted approach to malaria detection, incorporating microscopy, RDTs, and molecular methods. This approach is essential for interrupting malaria transmission and preventing re-introduction in Iran. The study underscores the critical

<summary>
* Over the past two decades, advancements in immunotherapy for cancer treatment have led to the development of various agents, including cytokine therapies, BCG therapy, and cellular therapies like sipuleucel-T for prostate cancer.
* The study explored the use of machine-learned Bayesian belief networks (ML-BBNs) to identify biomarkers of immune response to prostate cancer therapies, focusing on IgG responses to prostate-associated antigens.
* Results indicated that IgG responses to specific antigens were associated with different treatments and could potentially serve as biomarkers for clinical response, although larger sample sizes are needed for robust predictive models.
* The findings suggest that ML-BBN modeling is a promising method for identifying biomarkers in complex data sets, which could eventually support clinical applications in determining patient responses to vaccine therapies.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study investigates the use of piezoelectric materials, specifically polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) films, to mechanically stimulate bone growth through the converse piezoelectric effect. The films were coated with poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) to improve cell adhesion and ensure electrical insulation, and were tested in vivo on a Merino ewe.

• The actuator device, powered by a microcontroller and lithium battery, applied a 5V square wave at 1 Hz and 3 Hz for 15 minutes daily. Histological and histomorphometric analyses showed significantly higher bone formation around actuated devices compared to static controls, with increased mineral apposition rates and osteopontin (OPN) expression.

• Despite the promising results, the study noted the presence of a fibrous capsule around both actuated and static devices, suggesting the need for more biocompatible materials. The study was conducted on a single animal but with multiple devices, indicating the need for further research with larger sample sizes and longer implantation times.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study involved 90 individuals, with 60 oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients and 30 healthy controls, to estimate serum L-fucose levels.
• Serum L-fucose levels were significantly higher in OSCC patients (10.85 mg/dl) compared to healthy controls (3.47 mg/dl), with a p-value < 0.001.
• The study found a progressive increase in serum L-fucose levels with advancing stages of OSCC, from stage I to stage IV.
• No significant correlation was found between serum L-fucose levels and patient age or gender.
• Elevated serum L-fucose levels were associated with various cancers and other pathological conditions, not specific to OSCC alone.
• The study concluded that serum L-fucose levels could serve as a noninvasive, cost-effective biomarker for cancer detection, staging, and prognosis.
• The findings suggest that further large-scale investigations are needed to validate serum L-fucose as an effective tumor marker for oral cancer.
• The study emphasized the importance of excluding other diseases when estimating serum L-fucose levels in oral cancer patients.
</summary>

<summary>
* Lcn2 mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells and backcrossed onto the B6 background for 10 generations. They were housed in a pathogen-free facility at the University of Minnesota, following NIH guidelines. Age-matched male wild-type and lcn2 mice were allocated into groups and fed either an HFD or RCD.

* Glucose and insulin tolerance tests were conducted by intraperitoneal injection of glucose and insulin. Mice were fasted overnight for the glucose tolerance test and for 6 hours for insulin tolerance tests. Blood was collected via the tail vein at multiple time points.

* Adipose tissue was obtained from the epididymal and inguinal fat pad of wild-type and lcn2 mice fed an RCD. Tissue samples were fixed in osmium tetroxide and incubated for 48 hours. Adipose cell size was determined using a Beckman Coulter Multisizer III.

* Lcn2 mice were significantly heavier than wild-type mice on either an HFD or RCD. The weight of white and brown fat pads was significantly higher in HFD-fed lcn2 mice. Both HFD-fed and aged lcn2 mice showed significantly higher weights of liver, heart, kidney, and spleen.

* Lcn2 mice displayed cold sensitivity and could not survive when exposed to 4°C for more than 10 hours. Cold exposure caused a significant drop in rectal temperature in lcn2 mice. Lcn2 mice expressed significantly lower levels of UCP-1 and PGC-1 genes in BAT upon HFD feeding.

* Lcn2 mice developed more severe systemic insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and hypoadiponectinemia under the HFD condition. Insulin-stimulated Akt phosphorylation in liver, muscle, and adipose cells was significantly reduced in lcn2 mice. The expression levels of insulin receptor substrate-1 protein were markedly reduced in WAT of lcn2 mice on an HFD.

* The gene expression of proinflammatory cytokines TNF and MCP-1 were upregulated in adipose tissue of HFD-fed lcn2 mice. Arginase 1 and IL-10 expression were downregulated in the liver of HFD-fed lcn2 mice. Lcn2 mice demonstrated a significant increase in lipid accumulation in the liver.

* Lcn2 mice on an RCD had significantly higher serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and free fatty acids.

<summary>
* Male Wistar rats were used to study non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH) by administering LPS and methylprednisolone, with some rats subjected to hindlimb unloading to prevent weight bearing. The study aimed to determine if weight bearing influences the development of ONFH.
* Histopathological analysis showed that both weight-bearing (WB) and non-weight-bearing (NWB) rats developed ONFH at similar rates, with no significant difference between the groups. This suggests that weight bearing does not contribute to the initial development of ONFH.
* No osteonecrosis was observed in the humeral heads of either WB or NWB rats, indicating that the condition was specific to the femoral head. The study followed ethical guidelines and protocols approved by the Sapporo Medical University.
* The results imply that the rat model can help elucidate the pathogenesis of ONFH and devise prevention strategies, but it may not be useful for studying the mechanism of femoral head collapse. The study concludes that weight bearing is not related to the development of non-traumatic ONFH in rats.
</summary>

<summary>
* Nurses, who form the majority of the global healthcare workforce, are crucial for informing health policy reforms due to their close interaction with patients and their insights into health service delivery. Despite their importance, nurses have historically had limited involvement in national policy and political decisions, particularly in lower-income settings where they make up a larger proportion of the workforce. This underengagement is attributed to factors such as lack of awareness, inadequate knowledge and skills, and limited opportunities to contribute to policy decisions.

* Gender differences also play a role in nurses' limited participation in policy processes, with nursing being predominantly viewed as a woman's occupation and men typically occupying positions of power and decision-making. In Kenya, the lack of policy focus in nursing education programs further contributes to this issue. Strategies to enhance nurses' engagement include assuming formal leadership positions, lobbying and advocacy through professional organizations, and integrating policy and politics courses in nursing training.

* Empirical studies in the African context reveal that nurses' involvement in policy development is limited and inconsistent, with poor communication of policies and lack of resources for implementation. The study in Kenya applied a critical theory perspective to examine nurses' involvement in national health policy processes, highlighting the need for more inclusive decision-making structures. The findings indicate that nurses are often excluded from policy decisions, leading to poor policy implementation and lack of motivation among frontline nurses.

* To improve nurses' participation in policy processes, actions such as increasing nurses' representation on policy-related structures, consulting frontline nurses during policy development, and empowering nurses through training are recommended. Nurses should also be encouraged to diversify their knowledge, collaborate with other health professionals, and take up leadership roles. The study emphasizes the importance of addressing hierarchies, gender issues, and the need for continuous quality improvement mechanisms in the health care system.

* Finally, the study suggests that nursing educators should introduce courses on policy and policy processes in the nursing curriculum to enhance nurses' awareness and competency in policy-making. Developing skills in research and evidence-based policy-making is also crucial for nurses to influence policy decisions effectively. The study calls for further examination of the competencies held by nurse leaders and the deeply embedded hierarchies and power processes that sustain the status quo in policy change processes. Future research should focus on these aspects to better understand and improve nurses' involvement in health policy change.
</summary>

<summary>
* UTI is a common issue in infants and young children, with varying frequency, symptoms, and causative organisms based on sex, age, and gender. Neonates often present with non-specific symptoms, necessitating a complete sepsis workup and a 7 to 14-day antibiotic course. Emerging antibiotic resistance, especially to ampicillin, complicates early treatment decisions.

* Clinical manifestations of UTI in neonates are systemic and non-specific, including fever, irritability, lethargy, vomiting, and jaundice. The prevalence of UTI ranges from 4-25% in very low birth weight infants to 0.1-1% in term infants. UTI in newborns can lead to urosepsis or neonatal sepsis, often managed as sepsis cases.

* Most UTIs in infants are caused by gram-negative bacilli, with E. coli being the most prevalent organism. Other causative Enterobacteriaceae include Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Citrobacter, and Proteus. Gram-positive bacteria like Staphylococcus and Enterococcus are less commonly retrieved from neonates with UTI.

* The study aimed to review UTI cases in the neonatal division of Bahrami Children's Hospital over eight years. Data were extracted from hospital records, including age, sex, urine sample collection method, culture results, and antibiogram reports. The study used a case series design with non-random sampling to include all UTI cases from 2004 to 2012.

* UTI was defined as a pure growth of single bacteria from a suprapubic aspirate or 10 cfu/ml from a catheterized urine sample. Cases with more than one UTI episode were analyzed separately if they occurred more than 14 days apart. Mixed growth urine cultures and cases diagnosed via urine bag samples were excluded.

* A total of 73 cases met the inclusion criteria, with boys constituting 69.9% of the study population. Four bacteria were isolated: E. coli, Enterobacter, Klebsiella, and S. epidermidis. E. coli was the most prevalent, showing high resistance to ampicillin, cefixime, and cephalexin.

* E. coli showed the highest sensitivity to cefotaxime, norfloxacin, and ciprofloxacin. Enterobacter exhibited high resistance to amikacin and ampicillin but high sensitivity to ceftazidime and norfloxacin. Klebsiella and S. epidermidis were completely resistant to

<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of inherited disorders causing adrenal enzyme deficiency, with 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD) being the most common variant. Treatment involves glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement, but achieving natural circadian rhythms of cortisol release is challenging.
• A study of 26 CAH patients in Tunisia found that 42.3% had MRI abnormalities, including white matter hyperintensities and temporal lobe atrophy. Poor hormonal control due to non-compliance with medication was a significant factor in these abnormalities.
• White matter changes were often subclinical and located in periventricular regions or cerebellar areas. Hormonal imbalances and exogenous glucocorticoids are likely contributors to these MRI findings.
• The study also noted hippocampal dysgenesis and smaller amygdala volumes in some patients, potentially linked to cognitive and emotional issues. More research is needed to understand the relationship between brain abnormalities, CAH phenotypes, and treatment regimens.
</summary>

<summary>
• The delivery of the human genome draft sequence by publicly funded and corporate projects is expected to lead to significant biomedical advances, requiring biologists to adeptly navigate vast genomic DNA data. Beneath the seemingly featureless genomic landscape lies valuable knowledge awaiting exploitation. Surveying and signposting this landscape will guide experiments addressing specific hypotheses about gene function.

• Different biologists have varying interests under the term 'function,' from designing inhibitors using protein structural data to relating genotype to phenotype. Universal vocabularies are needed for genome surveyors to make the genome's secrets accessible to all scientific communities. Two common ways of annotating genes include integrating diverse information sources and predicting evolutionary relationships.

• Websites like LocusLink, GeneCards, and Ensembl integrate information relevant to individual human genes, including sequence information and descriptions of molecular and cellular function. However, this annotation is currently limited to experimentally characterized genes. The second type of annotation relies on predicted evolutionary relationships, defining genes as homologs, paralogs, or orthologs.

• Homologous gene products often have similar tertiary structures and functions, making homology-based annotation valuable. However, homology is based on evolution, not function, and may only provide an approximate direction for empirical determination of function. The first sequenced genomes were annotated by searching sequence databases with each predicted gene product.

• Domain architectures in proteins show that evolution has fused and divided genes using pre-existing components. Domains are homologous portions of sequences that have survived evolutionary tests and represent the finite vocabulary of protein evolution. Resources like Pfam, SMART, and InterPro provide domain annotations, aiding in the prediction of protein functions.

• Proteome annotation by domain content implies that a gene product's function is a synthesis of its component parts' generalized functions. This method provides the best predictions for the uncharacterized majority of human genes. Annotation is achieved automatically, which is crucial as newly sequenced genomes are in a high state of flux.

• Comparative proteomics has shown that domain 'invention' in chordates has made a minor contribution to proteome diversity, with expansions and contractions of domain families playing a significant role. Future proteome comparisons should aim to understand the biology underlying domain family size variability. The Gene Ontology Project (GO) is creating a hierarchy of defined terms to standardize functional descriptions across genomics.
</summary>

<summary>
* Over the last 25 years, heart rate monitors (HRMs) have become widely used in sports and sports science, with handy HRMs and flexible chest belts making heart rate measurement accessible for training and research. The validity and reliability of these tools are high compared to ECG measurements for both heart rate (HR) and heart rate variability (HRV). Recent developments have focused on real-time monitoring instead of post-exercise evaluation. Several systems are available, including Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.

* The study aimed to compare these systems in a field test, evaluating operating distance, validity against a commercially available ECG, and the installation and use of software and hardware. Twelve active people participated, with ten men from an amateur soccer team conducting an online field test during a real football match. One male subject participated for HR monitoring system validity against ECG, and one female subject was involved in operating distance measurement. Due to the low case number, data for ECG validation and distance measurement are considered a pilot study.

* The rating system was subdivided into three main categories: measurement, software, and hardware, with measurement being the core focus. The rating system was set in favor of measurement, represented by 200 out of 500 scores. The remaining 300 scores were equally divided between hardware quality and software usability. Subcategories were weighted subjectively by the authors, considering team sports monitoring of 10 or more subjects in parallel.

* An independent observer rated subcategories like instruction manual, packing, chest belts quality, and initial software handling. The remaining categories were judged by an experienced person, except for wearing comfort and failure quota in the field. Wearing comfort was evaluated via a short anonymous questionnaire completed by all 12 participants. The main field test measured the failure ratio during the first half of a real soccer match.

* The receiver was positioned three meters from the midline of the soccer ground to improve transmission distance. A mean failure ratio was determined only with transmitters sending valid data, with each 1% deviation/loss of the whole duration measurement subtracted by 10 scores. Distance measurement was conducted on an uphill street with a constant slope, using a GPS device to measure distance. Tests were conducted twice, and the mean value was taken as the maximal range.

* Comparison against ECG was conducted in a laboratory using the Vicardio ECP-6 standard ECG tool. A maximum score of 30 could be obtained, with a deviation of 1 beat per minute

<summary>
* In the 1960s, McCulloch and Till defined stem cells by their ability to self-renew, proliferate, and exhibit multipotency. These characteristics must be induced in vitro for classification. Cell surface proteins help isolate and track stem cells.

* Lung epithelia have low proliferative rates, making stem cell identification challenging. Despite this, stem cells have been identified in the lung, especially in response to airway injury. These cells exhibit self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency.

* Proximal airways contain tracheal basal cells expressing keratin-5 (k5) and keratin-14 (k14). These cells can proliferate and give rise to multiple phenotypes after injury. Squamous cell carcinoma often arises from k5 stem cells.

* Middle airways have Clara cells that can act as facultative progenitor cells. Clara-cell secretory protein (ccsp)-positive cells in neuroepithelial bodies (neb) can repopulate airways after injury. Small cell lung carcinomas contain cells expressing cd44 and mdr1 markers.

* Distal airways have pluripotent ccsp cells at the bronchoalveolar duct junction (badj). These cells express surfactant protein c (sp-c), stem cell antigen-1 (sca-1), and cd34. There is debate over the exact markers for distal lung stem cells.

* Lung adenocarcinoma and bronchioloalveolar carcinoma are linked to stem cells from the badj region. The cancer stem cell hypothesis suggests rare, multipotent cells drive tumor growth. These cells lead to tumor heterogeneity through aberrant differentiation.

* Stem cells express anti-apoptotic and drug-resistant proteins, explaining chemotherapy resistance. Chemoresistant lung cancer stem cells may continue to proliferate after treatment. This has led to interest in targeted therapies against specific cell types.

* Tumor subpopulations with stem-like properties have been identified in lung cancer specimens. Cd133 cells can grow indefinitely and form diverse tumors. Patients with more cd133 cells have worse prognosis and increased resistance to cisplatin-based therapies.

* The role of stem cells in lung tumorigenesis is supported by their presence in tumors and matching stem cell niches. It is difficult to distinguish between true and facultative stem cells. Future research may improve lung cancer management by targeting stem cells.
</summary>

<summary>
• Tubularized incised plate (TIP) repair is recommended for distal penile hypospadias and has shown excellent results in various cases. This study examines the role of urethral plate character in the success of TIP repair among 100 children in Yemen.
• The study categorized patients based on urethral plate width (>8 mm and <8 mm) and shape (flat, cleft, deeply grooved). Results showed a higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration in patients with narrower plates (<8 mm).
• Postoperative complications were assessed, with 8% developing fistula and 12% failing 8 fr calibration. Patients with flat urethral plates had higher complication rates, though not statistically significant.
• The study suggests that TIP urethroplasty offers good cosmetic and functional results for primary anterior penile hypospadias. Augmentation with buccal mucosal graft (BMG) is recommended for narrow and inelastic urethral plates to improve outcomes.
</summary>

<summary>
* A prototype was developed to measure the in vivo debonding force of orthodontic brackets using a strain gauge directly connected to the pliers' claw.
* The prototype's bond strength measurements were compared with those obtained from a universal testing machine, showing no significant statistical difference.
* The prototype was found to be reliable and not influenced by the way it was held, unlike previous devices.
* The study suggests that the prototype could be a useful tool for measuring bond strength in vivo, with the adhesive remnant index indicating minimal enamel damage.
</summary>

<summary>
* Trichomonas vaginalis infection is a common curable sexually transmitted infection, with WHO estimating 173 million new cases annually. It is associated with adverse reproductive health outcomes such as pelvic inflammatory disease, low infant birth weight, and premature delivery. Trichomoniasis also increases the transmission and acquisition of other STDs, including HIV.

* The frequency of trichomonal infection is not monitored in most countries, and control programs are lacking. Peruvian STI guidelines do not include diagnostic testing for trichomonas, relying instead on syndromic management. The infection is likely more common than understood, with asymptomatic cases contributing to community-level transmission.

* A cross-sectional study was conducted from 2003 to 2005 in Peru, focusing on socially marginalized women from low-income neighborhoods in Lima, Trujillo, and Chiclayo. Participants were recruited from various venues and were required to meet specific criteria, including age and sexual activity. Data collection involved a structured survey and biological specimen collection for STI testing.

* The study found that women with trichomonas infection were more likely to be older, less educated, and single. There was no significant association between trichomonas infection and vaginal symptoms like discharge or painful urination. Women with HSV-2 and syphilis infections were twice as likely to have trichomonas infection.

* The prevalence of trichomonas infection was higher among older women, suggesting long-term infections that do not resolve spontaneously. This finding indicates that screening programs focused on younger women may miss many cases. The study highlights the need for screening and treatment programs to control the spread of trichomonas infection.

* The study's sample size was small, limiting the power to assess multivariate models. The results may not be generalizable to other female populations, but standardized interviews helped minimize biases. The asymptomatic nature of trichomonas infection suggests that syndromic management may lead to both over and under-treatment.

* The study emphasizes the importance of screening and treating sex partners of infected women to prevent reinfection and reduce prevalence. Improved disease control activities are needed to reduce adverse reproductive health outcomes associated with trichomoniasis. Further studies are required to determine if screening and treatment will improve reproductive health and birth outcomes.
</summary>

<summary>
* Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS) is a severe childhood epilepsy characterized by multiple seizure types, cognitive impairment, and a poor prognosis. It is difficult to treat due to its encephalopathic nature and the frequent occurrence of various seizure types, often requiring polypharmacy which can lead to cumulative side effects and drug interactions. Valproic acid is commonly recommended as the first-line treatment, with other medications like lamotrigine, rufinamide, and topiramate as second-line options. Non-pharmacological treatments such as the ketogenic diet and vagus nerve stimulation are also considered when medications fail.

* Rufinamide, a novel anticonvulsant, has shown promise in treating LGS by reducing seizure frequency and severity with a good safety profile. Clinical trials have demonstrated its efficacy, particularly in reducing tonic-atonic seizures, and it is well tolerated with minimal cognitive side effects. However, careful monitoring is required due to potential drug interactions, especially with valproic acid. Further studies are needed to establish its definitive role in the treatment of LGS and to compare its effectiveness with other anticonvulsants.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study on Iberian wall lizards (Podarcis hispanica) in central Spain found significant interpopulational differences in morphology and chemical signals, suggesting potential premating reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation.
• Chemosensory recognition experiments indicated that lizards could discriminate scents from different populations, with males showing a preference for scents from their own population, highlighting the role of chemical signals in sexual interactions and potential speciation processes.
</summary>

<summary>
• The scientific activity of researchers is reflected in published papers, which are validated by peers and serve as indicators of knowledge development.
• Major international databases like Medline/PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents, along with Brazilian databases like LILACS and SciELO, index these publications.
• The study focused on the scientific production of full professors at the Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de São Paulo (FMUSP) from 2001 to 2006.
• A total of 1,960 articles were published by 66 full professors, with 68.7% in international journals and 31.3% in Brazilian journals.
• The average publication rate increased from 3.8 articles per professor in 2001 to 5.9 in 2006, with most articles being co-authored.
• Journals with impact factors (IFs) between 1 and 5 published 47.7% of the articles, while only a few Brazilian journals had assigned IFs.
• Almost half of the published articles were cited, generating a total of 9,335 citations, with 91% of citations from international journals.
• The study highlighted the higher publication rate of full professors compared to the overall faculty, indicating significant scientific productivity.
• The data from this study can be used to analyze and compare the scientific output of FMUSP with other institutions in Brazil and globally.
</summary>

<summary>
• According to WHO experts, rubella infection during early pregnancy has a 90% chance of passing the virus to the fetus, potentially causing congenital rubella syndrome (CRS). Vaccination of susceptible women, especially those of reproductive age, can prevent CRS and its serious complications. The primary goal of rubella vaccination is to prevent congenital infection and CRS, which affects around 110,000 infants annually in developing countries. Rubella is still endemic in some regions, causing outbreaks in winter and early spring.

• The RA27/3 virus strain is the most commonly used rubella vaccine globally, inducing seroconversion in 95% of vaccinated individuals. Various seroepidemiological studies have been conducted worldwide to assess the need for rubella vaccination. In Australia, rubella vaccination for schoolgirls since 1971 significantly decreased CRS cases. Denmark's vaccination policy evolved from optional schoolgirl vaccination in 1974 to extensive two-dose MMR vaccination in 1987, raising anti-rubella antibody levels to 96.5%.

• In Iran, several studies indicated varying levels of rubella immunity among females, leading to the inclusion of rubella and mumps vaccines in the national vaccination plan in 2003. The mass vaccination program targeted 33,579,082 people aged 5 to 25, achieving a 98% vaccination rate. This resulted in a significant decrease in measles and rubella cases to less than one per million. A study in Kermanshah showed a rise in rubella immunity from 79.6% in unvaccinated girls to 99.3% in vaccinated girls.

• The study in Kermanshah revealed a significant decrease in negative antibody rates from 20.42% to 0.7% post-vaccination. This finding aligns with other studies in Iran, showing increased immunity rates after the 2003 mass vaccination. For example, Mashhad's immunity rate rose from 70.38% to 98.5%, and Shahre-Kord's from 86% to 96%. Hamadan's anti-rubella antibody levels increased from 83.5% to 98.4% two years after the vaccination program.

• The effectiveness of the RA27/3 vaccine is demonstrated by the elimination of rubella and CRS in the Western Hemisphere and several European countries. Iran's mass rubella vaccination in 2003 significantly increased anti-rubella antibodies and immunity in high-risk populations. Due to the low susceptibility rate of less than

<summary>
• The advent of cell type-specific molecular markers and gene-specific RNA probes has enabled detailed analysis of developmental morphogenesis in various biological systems, with whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) being a key technique. Initially performed with radioactive probes, WISH was simplified with nonradioactive probes and is now widely used in systems like Drosophila, Xenopus, and zebrafish. However, chromogenic multilabeling techniques have limitations in discerning overlapping expression regions, and fluorescent methods offer potential solutions but face challenges in implementation, especially in embryos with high autofluorescence.

• Quantum dots (QDs) have emerged as promising inorganic fluorophores for RNA detection due to their strong fluorescence, wide excitation spectra, and resistance to photobleaching. Despite their advantages, QDs face issues like penetration in embryos and aggregation. Proteinase K treatment has been found to improve QD penetration in Xenopus embryos, allowing for deep tissue staining and higher resolution RNA detection. QDs have been successfully used to visualize multiple RNA probes simultaneously, providing higher resolution data than current techniques.

• The study demonstrated that QDs could penetrate Xenopus embryos and provide specific deep tissue staining, overcoming the limitations of traditional fluorophores. QDs were used to detect endogenous messenger RNAs with high signal intensity and resolution, confirming their effectiveness in WISH experiments. The use of QDs allowed for more accurate determination of transcript expression patterns, as shown in optical section images. The ability to detect multiple transcripts simultaneously with QDs was also established, highlighting their potential for multiplexing.

• The new QD-based WISH protocol offers significant advantages over traditional methods, including improved resolution and the ability to visualize intracellular mRNA localization. The protocol does not require enzymatic amplification, which enhances resolving ability and reduces diffusion issues. QDs provide strong signal intensities sufficient for imaging on regular epifluorescence microscopes without the need for confocal microscopy. The study suggests that QDs could be introduced as alternative fluorophores in other fluorescent in situ hybridization assays, expanding their uses in biology.

• Overall, the results demonstrate that QD in situ hybridization is a viable alternative to current ISH protocols, offering unprecedented resolution and strong signal intensities. The method is particularly advantageous for highly autofluorescent embryos like Xenopus, where traditional methods fall short. The successful implementation of QDs in Xenopus suggests that they will find applications in other developmental models. The study concludes that QDs could significantly enhance the study of mRNA localization and expression in various biological

<summary>
* Pancreatic cancer, particularly pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), has the highest mortality rate among cancers in the U.S., with a median survival time of about four months post-diagnosis. The survival rates vary significantly based on demographic and clinical factors, and less than 20% of patients are suitable for surgical resection, which is the most impactful treatment on survival.
* Cox proportional hazards regression models have been used to estimate survival probabilities for PDAC patients, considering factors like age, gender, race, tumor stage, and treatment type. These models have been validated for reliability and generalizability using SEER data from 18,352 cases diagnosed between 2004 and 2009, showing good calibration and discrimination abilities.
* A web-based, real-time prognostic tool has been developed based on these models to estimate survival and conditional survival probabilities for PDAC patients. This tool provides personalized survival estimates and standard errors, aiding clinicians in making informed treatment decisions. However, limitations include the lack of chemotherapy data and potential inaccuracies for small patient subpopulations.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study recruited Japanese patients with CLI who underwent PTA at Kansai Rosai Hospital between 2003 and 2009. Patients were evaluated for limb ischemia by angiography and managed according to TASC and TASC II guidelines.
• PTA was the first-choice procedure for revascularization unless lesions were heavily calcified or had diffuse occlusions. Major amputation was considered when revascularization failed to relieve rest pain or control foot lesions.
• The study analyzed preoperative variables such as sex, age, ADLs, Fontaine stage, infection, diabetic condition, hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking, hemodialysis, and serum albumin level. Diabetic condition was determined by the presence of diabetes and glycemic control evaluated by A1C.
• Data were presented as means and standard deviations for continuous variables or percentages for dichotomous variables. Limb salvage and survival were plotted using the Kaplan-Meier method, with differences assessed by a log-rank test.
• A total of 278 CLI patients undergoing primary PTA were recruited, with revascularization performed on aorto-iliac, femoro-popliteal, and infrapopliteal lesions. Diabetic patients had a higher prevalence of Fontaine stage IV and hemodialysis compared to non-diabetic patients.
• The follow-up period was 90 ± 72 weeks, during which 48 patients underwent major amputations and 89 died. The leading cause of death was cardiac and vascular disease, followed by infection.
• Diabetic patients had a higher rate of major amputation compared to non-diabetic patients, but similar life prognosis. The presence of diabetes was independently associated with major amputation, with an adjusted HR of 3.101.
• Mortality was associated with age, impaired ADLs, hemodialysis, and serum albumin level. A1C level was independently associated with major amputation in diabetic patients, with an adjusted HR of 1.349 per 1% increment.
• The study divided the A1C dataset into quartiles to analyze the relationship between A1C levels and major amputation risk. Higher A1C quartiles were significantly associated with increased risk of major amputation.
• Diabetes with A1C ≥ 6.8%, infection, and hemodialysis were significantly associated with major amputation. The accumulation of these prognostic factors increased the risk of major amputation, with extremely poor prognosis for those with all three risk factors.

<summary>
• Human cystic echinococcosis (CE), caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is a significant parasitic zoonosis acquired through accidental ingestion of eggs from infected dogs. The disease is prevalent in regions with close contact between intermediate and definitive hosts, typically sheep and dogs. CE in humans manifests with fluid-filled cysts in organs like the liver and lungs, diagnosed through radiology and serology. Post-surgical relapses or treatment failures can occur due to nonradical procedures or spillage of parasite material.

• Postsurgical follow-up of CE patients is crucial to detect newly growing cysts early. Serology is commonly used for postoperative monitoring, but the persistence of anti-E. granulosus antibodies complicates relapse diagnosis. Various serologic techniques have been evaluated, but there is a need for improved immunodiagnostic tools. Identifying new antigens that classify patients into cured and noncured categories is one approach.

• This study examined antigenic bands essential for CE serologic diagnosis using immunoblotting analysis. Blood samples were collected from 50 CE patients, 40 non-CE patients, and 20 healthy controls. CE patients received antihelminthic treatment and underwent surgical procedures, with samples taken pre- and post-treatment. Hydatid cyst fluid antigen (HCF) was prepared from infected sheep livers, and antigen protein concentration was estimated using the Lowry method.

• The study found that antigenic bands with molecular weights of 52, 24, 39, 46, 63, and 60-61 kDa were specific for hydatid disease. These bands showed high diagnostic value, with significant decreases in 24 and 39 kDa bands in post-operative samples. The 24 and 39 kDa bands persisted in patients with relapses, indicating their potential as diagnostic markers. Western blotting proved useful for diagnosing hydatidosis and post-surgical monitoring.

• The study highlighted the variability in results due to differences in antigen sources, purification protocols, and experimental conditions. The 57 kDa band cross-reacted with antibodies from other parasitic infections, indicating non-specificity. Western blotting showed the disappearance of some bands post-surgery, while others persisted, aligning with differences in immunoglobulin reactivity. Antibodies against 24 and 39 kDa proteins were good markers for post-surgical monitoring.

• Western blotting is a valuable method for post-surgical monitoring of CE, as it can detect the appearance or disappearance of specific antigenic

• Obesity is a prevalent metabolic disease globally, often assessed using BMI, WC, and WHR, with newer indices like WHtR, VAI, and BAI gaining attention for their role in evaluating cardiovascular risk and metabolic complications.
• This study aimed to examine the relationship between various obesity indices (BMI, WC, WHR, WHtR, BAI, VAI) and serum lipid levels in 66 obese non-diabetic patients, divided into three groups based on obesity class.
• Significant negative correlations were found between BMI and TC, LDL-C, HDL-C, and between WC, WHR, VAI, and HDL-C, while positive correlations were observed between WC, WHR, and TG/HDL-C, and between VAI and several lipid parameters.

• The study found that patients with class III obesity had significantly lower mean serum levels of TC and LDL-C compared to those with class I obesity, despite no differences in lipid-lowering treatment.
• The results suggest that increased adipose tissue may decrease LDL-C levels through mechanisms like increased LDL-C receptor activity or dilution of the circulating LDL-C pool.
• The study also noted that the relationship between BMI and LDL-C levels is complex and influenced by factors such as age and sex, with higher LDL-C levels seen in younger obese women.

• The study observed that WC values were positively correlated with serum TG levels and negatively correlated with HDL-C levels, with stronger correlations in women compared to men.
• Data from other studies support the findings that increasing BMI results in decreasing HDL-C levels and increasing TG levels, although these studies were conducted in general populations.
• The study's results align with previous research showing negative correlations between WC and HDL-C levels, and positive correlations between WHR and TG/HDL-C ratio.

• The study highlights the significant association between obesity, particularly abdominal obesity, and dyslipidemia, mainly characterized by reductions in HDL-C levels.
• VAI demonstrated the strongest correlation with TG and HDL-C levels, as well as with lipid indices like TC/HDL-C, LDL-C/HDL-C, and TG/HDL-C.
• The positive correlation between WHR and TG/HDL-C ratio observed in this study is consistent with findings from other research.

• The study emphasizes the importance of newer obesity indices like VAI, WHtR, and BAI in assessing lipid parameters, especially in obese patients with dyslipidemias.
• One strength of the study is its focus on obese patients grouped by obesity level, particularly

<summary>
• The study aimed to investigate the prevalence of internet addiction and its association with psychopathology among college students in Mumbai, involving 987 participants aged 16-18 years. Tools used included Young's Internet Addiction Test (IAT) and the Duke Health Profile to measure internet addiction severity and health status, respectively.
• Results showed that 74.5% were moderate users, 24.8% were possible addicts, and 0.7% were addicts, with males more likely to be addicted. Addicts primarily used the internet in the evenings and nights and had higher anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores.
• The study found no significant relationship between internet addiction and hours of use per day, but addicts often lost track of time online. The findings suggest that internet addiction may be more common in males and could be linked to poor mental and physical health, highlighting the need for early intervention and boundary-setting.
</summary>

<summary>
• The frequency response of the resonators was measured using a downmixing method, with the device electrostatically actuated by applying a driving voltage to a side-gate parallel to the resonator. To reduce parasitic signals, the drive signal was set to half the actuation frequency, making the amplitude of motion proportional to the square of the actuation voltage. A bias voltage was used to down-mix resistance changes, and the low-frequency readout signal was detected using a lock-in amplifier.
• Typical measurement values included a 1.5 V bias voltage at a measurement frequency of 500 kHz, with all measurements performed in a vacuum chamber at 10 mbar pressure and room temperature. Thermomechanical noise was measured using the same setup but with the drive electrode disconnected. Measurements were taken with a lock-in amplifier, which also generated the drive and bias signals.
• The Allan deviation was measured in an open-loop configuration, with frequency stability extracted from the resonator's response actuated at resonance frequency with a fixed driving frequency. The phase of the measured signal was monitored over time and transformed into frequency fluctuations using the phase response of the resonator. Close to the resonance frequency, this phase response was linear, and using the complete phase response instead of the linearization did not significantly alter the Allan deviation.
• Harmonics at multiples of 50 Hz were filtered out during post-processing. Using this method, n samples of the resonance frequency were obtained, each averaged over an integration time. The Allan deviation for this integration time was defined and calculated using a specific equation.
• To obtain frequency stability for higher integration times, initial samples were averaged in groups, and the Allan deviation for the new array was calculated. This process was repeated until the number of samples was too low for statistical significance. Correlation measurements were performed by simultaneously measuring the resonator's response at different frequencies within its bandwidth.
• The measurement setup for correlation was based on a previously described method but doubled the signals using two drive signals, two bias signals, and two measurement signals. Care was taken to keep the resonator in the linear regime by choosing appropriate drive signal amplitudes. The two measurement frequencies were chosen to avoid cross-talk, such as 302 kHz and 367 kHz.
• Although a down-mixing setup was used, correlation could also be measured with a homodyne method. Phase traces were converted to frequency traces corresponding to different integration times. The complete phase response of the resonator was used rather than the linear approximation for this conversion.

<summary>
• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the U.S., and aspirin therapy is recommended for its prevention. However, many studies fail to accurately assess physician recommendations for aspirin use.
• The study analyzed data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2011-2012, focusing on adults aged 40 and older. It aimed to evaluate patient use of aspirin and reported physician recommendations for CVD prevention.
• Results showed that less than a third of primary prevention patients were recommended aspirin by their doctors, with high-risk patients receiving fewer recommendations than expected. Compliance with physician recommendations was high among those advised to take aspirin.
• Logistic regression indicated that factors like education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care influenced the likelihood of receiving an aspirin recommendation. The study highlighted a disconnect between objective CVD risk and physician recommendations for aspirin use.
</summary>

<summary>
* Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) during oxidative metabolism, which play a crucial role in cellular signaling and differentiation. Increased mitochondrial content and ROS levels correlate with stem cell differentiation, while low levels are associated with stem cell maintenance.
* In the epidermis, mitochondrial ROS generation is essential for activating transcriptional programs like Notch and β-catenin, which promote differentiation and hair growth. Conditional deletion of TFAM in keratinocytes impairs differentiation, highlighting the importance of mitochondrial metabolism in epidermal homeostasis.
* Mitochondrial calcium uptake stimulates TCA cycle enzymes, promoting respiration and ROS production necessary for keratinocyte differentiation. Uncoupling protein 2 (UCP2) inhibits oxidative metabolism and differentiation, suggesting it acts as a metabolic switch in stem cell fate decisions.
* Mitochondrial metabolism also provides substrates for histone acetylation and demethylation, which are crucial for gene regulation during differentiation. Understanding the interplay between cellular metabolism and differentiation programs could lead to regenerative therapies and treatments for metabolic diseases.
</summary>

<summary>
* Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a single-stranded RNA virus from the Flaviviridae family, and its study has advanced in functional analysis and therapeutic implications. Due to low viral levels in serum, HCV diagnosis often uses branched chain DNA signal amplification assay and reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Pathologists need simple and reliable histochemical techniques for detecting viral pathogens in biopsy tissue samples.

* Immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization (ISH) have been used to detect HCV in human liver tissue, but these methods are not yet reproducible enough. Reliable histochemical techniques for detecting HCV in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) liver tissues are particularly needed for routine diagnostics. The study established an ISH technique using a locked nucleic acid (LNA) probe and biotin-free tyramide amplification system (CSAII) for detecting HCV-RNA in FFPE liver sections.

* Positive controls included humanized liver samples from HCV-infected chimeric mice, with FFPE tissue sections prepared. The study used 13 humanized liver specimens from HCV-infected chimeric mice and 11 needle biopsy liver specimens of chronic hepatitis C from Fujita Health University Hospital. Additional samples included hepatitis B virus (HBV)-infected chronic hepatitis, virus-negative fatty liver, autoimmune hepatitis, and surgically removed HCC lesions caused by HCV or HBV infection.

* The study evaluated the activity of inflammation and degree of fibrosis using the new Inuyama classification (1996). Serum HCV-RNA levels were measured using an RT-PCR assay, and HCV subtypes were determined with nested RT-PCR. The LNA-modified oligonucleotide probe targeted the highly conserved HCV 5-untranslated region (HCV-5UTR).

* The ISH technique involved quenching endogenous peroxidase activity, digesting sections with proteinase K, and hybridizing with the LNA-modified oligonucleotide probe. Sections were then treated with horseradish-peroxidase-labeled antidigoxygenin antibody and fluorescein-isothiocyanate-conjugated tyramide for signal amplification. The reaction products were visualized, and nuclei were counterstained with Mayer's hematoxylin.

* Specificity of the ISH technique was verified by treating sections with DNase and RNase before hybridization. Human-specific CK8/18 monoclonal antibody was used to distinguish mouse hepatocytes from chimer

* The text discusses concerns about endocrine-disrupting chemicals affecting thyroid systems in vertebrates, particularly focusing on amphibian metamorphosis as a model for studying these effects. The OECD and EPA have established guidelines using frog metamorphosis assays to screen for potential endocrine disruptors, emphasizing the importance of thyroid gland histology as a primary endpoint.
* Various chemicals have been shown to disrupt thyroid hormone synthesis and metabolism in amphibians, leading to developmental delays and morphological changes. Validation studies have confirmed the sensitivity of thyroid histopathology for detecting antithyroidal activity, though it is less effective for identifying weak agonistic effects.
</summary>

• Cesarean sections (CS) are necessary for life-saving interventions to prevent maternal or perinatal complications, but the rate of CS without medical indication is increasing globally. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a 10-15% rate of CS based on countries with the lowest maternal and neonatal mortality rates. Many countries, including Iran, have CS rates far higher than the recommended range. The debate on the best practices (vaginal delivery (VD) vs. CS) to minimize postnatal morbidity remains controversial.

• The postpartum period is critical for women, leading to physiological, emotional, and social changes that affect their quality of life (QOL). Several studies confirm that socio-economic deficiencies and medical problems are risk factors for decreased QOL and depressive symptoms in women during the postnatal period. The mode of delivery and childbirth experience may have long-term effects on self-rated health. Conflicting studies exist on the association between type of delivery and health-related quality of life (HRQOL).

• A prospective study in Kashan, Iran, explored the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental HRQOL. The study included 365 women, with 342 completing the study after delivery (175 VD and 167 CS). QOL was assessed using the Iranian version of the Short Form-36 Health Survey (SF-36). The study found that women after VD had higher mean physical HRQOL scores than after CS, while mean mental HRQOL scores were similar among both groups.

• At 2 months postpartum, VD women had higher total physical health scores than CS women, with significant differences in physical functioning (PF) and role limitation due to physical problems (RP). At 4 months postpartum, VD women had higher scores in both total physical and mental health compared to CS women. Significant differences were found in PF, social functioning (SF), and emotional well-being (EW) subscales. The VD group showed more improvements in total mental HRQOL from 2 to 4 months postpartum.

• The study protocol was approved by the local research committee in Kashan University of Medical Sciences. There were no significant differences between VD and CS groups regarding socio-demographic characteristics. Maternal age ranged from 20 to 40, and up to 80% of VD was performed with episiotomy or laceration. The study highlighted the importance of careful assessment of predictor variables for poorer physical and mental health after childbirth to improve postpartum care quality.
